timeline.message: Fix #1871 - Handle period range searches better

timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: Someone might want to store genealogy data (or even ancestral disease information) that predates this date.
replies.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: On the other hand, we should check that these dates work okay on the main databases, esp the timestamp versions of them.
replies.author: fil512

replies.bodyText:
Did a bit of digging into supported limits in databases:


JDBC Timestamp Datatype Low Value -4713 and High Value 9999
MySQL 8: the range for DATETIME values is '1000-01-01 00:00:00.000000' to '9999-12-31 23:59:59.999999`
Postgresql 12: Timestamp [without time zone] Low Value 4713 BC and High Value 294276 AD
Oracle: Timestamp Low Value 4712 BC and High Value 9999 CE
H2: datetime2 Low Value -4713 and High Value 9999


I'm gonna go with 1001 - 9000 for safety
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: I'm surprised you didn't need the DatePredicate logic.  I guess those queries just never worked?
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText:
Yup. I'm happy about that aspect of this change, no modifications to the search predicate logic were required.
It's not as bad as it maybe seemed- Date range searches almost all worked, there are only 2 cases that didn't:

Indexed period with a lower bound and no upper bound, and then a search by date where the selector is gt ( a value > the lower bound)
Indexed period with an upper bound and no lower bound, and then a search by date where the selector is lt ( a value < the upper bound)
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: Did this case just not work, so the assert was commented out?
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: These tests weren't actually removed, I just moved them from FhirResourceDaoR4Test to FhirResourceDaoR4SearchNoFtTest.java in order to make them easier to find (that's where all the tests for the other search datatypes were, no idea why the date ones were here!)
replies.author: jamesagnew

replies.bodyText: Uncommented in the other class, and it does work now!
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: Does this work now if you uncomment it?  Should it work?
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: Ah good call! It totally does.
replies.author: jamesagnew
